notes.title: The Constitution as a System of Checks & Balances
notes.content: Explain separation of powers (Articles I–III) and mutual checks (veto/override, judicial review, Senate consent, impeachment). Use case illustrations (e.g., treaty ratification vs. executive agreements) and show how crises (Civil War, New Deal, Vietnam era) recalibrated the balance.
keyTakeaways: Checks & balances are dynamic—crises expand executive power, peacetime often recenters Congress/Courts.
Judicial review (Marbury) operationalizes constitutional supremacy.
Senate's treaty/appointment role is a structural foreign-policy check.

resources.title: Library of Congress — Defects in the Articles

notes.title: Bill of Rights (1791) — Scope, Origins & Exam Angles
notes.content: Know the 10 amendments' core protections, Anti-Federalist pressure for adoption, incorporation through the 14th Amendment, and recurring exam MCQs (date/name).
keyTakeaways: Ratified 1791; 12 proposed, 10 adopted.
Anti-Federalist advocacy was decisive for adoption.
Selective incorporation applied most rights to states.

resources.title: NARA — Congress Creates the Bill of Rights (booklet)

notes.title: Articles of Confederation — Weaknesses & Replacement
notes.content: Tie structural flaws (no taxing power, no regulation of commerce, weak executive/judiciary) to Shays' Rebellion, interstate disputes, and the call for the Philadelphia Convention.
keyTakeaways: Fiscal impotence + trade chaos pushed elites toward a new frame.
Federalist Papers argued for an 'energetic' national government.
Exam often asks for comparative table: Articles vs. Constitution.

resources.title: Founders Online — Madison on Confederation defects

notes.title: Federalists vs. Anti-Federalists
notes.content: Contrast visions: national energy vs. states' primacy; fear of consolidated power vs. fear of anarchy. Show how the Bill of Rights emerged as compromise.
keyTakeaways: Federalists used print campaigns (The Federalist) to sway ratification.
Anti-Federalists influenced rights protections and limits.
Debate frames later conflicts (Nullification, Civil War era).

resources.title: Library of Congress — Federalist Papers portal

notes.title: Manifest Destiny & Westward Expansion
notes.content: Define O'Sullivan's term (1845), link to Louisiana Purchase, Texas Annexation, Mexican Cession, Homestead Act, Native removal/conflict, and the slavery extension crisis.
keyTakeaways: Ideology + opportunity + state policy drove continental expansion.
Expansion intensified sectionalism (slave vs. free territories).
Know key acquisitions and dates for MCQs.

notes.title: Monroe Doctrine (1823) & Roosevelt Corollary
notes.content: Summarize the hemispheric non-colonization and non-interference principles; note later 'police power' corollary and 20th-century interventions.
keyTakeaways: Original message in Monroe's 7th Annual Address (Dec 2, 1823).
Roosevelt's 1904 corollary normalized interventionism without annexation.
Cite uses: Venezuela crisis, Caribbean interventions.

resources.title: Yale Avalon Project — Monroe Doctrine text

notes.title: From Republic to Empire? 1898 & After
notes.content: Explain Spanish-American War, annexations (Philippines, Guam, Puerto Rico), and debates (anti-imperialists vs. expansionists). Tie to Open Door & later Cold-War basing.
keyTakeaways: 1898 marks U.S. great-power status and overseas empire.
Debates over consent, citizenship, and constitutional rights in territories.
Use 1898 as pivot in exam essays on 'imperialist-colonialist power'.

notes.title: Causes of the Civil War — Economy, Slavery & Ideology
notes.content: Synthesize long-term (slavery expansion, economic models, political breakdown) and short-term (Kansas-Nebraska, Dred Scott, 1860 election) factors; include inevitability debate.
keyTakeaways: Sectional economic paths fed political polarization.
Territorial expansion repeatedly re-opened the slavery question.
Frame with competing constitutional visions (states' rights vs. Union).

notes.title: Evaluating Abraham Lincoln's Presidency
notes.content: Assess preservation of the Union, Emancipation Proclamation's wartime/legal logic, leadership style, civil liberties controversies, and Reconstruction beginnings.
keyTakeaways: Lincoln's crisis leadership redefined executive power.
War aims evolved from union to union-plus-emancipation.
Legacy debated: civil liberties vs. necessity in war.

notes.title: Jeffersonian vs. Jacksonian Democracy
notes.content: Compare agrarian republicanism, limited central power, and education (Jefferson) with mass politics, spoils system, Bank War, and Indian Removal (Jackson).
keyTakeaways: Both valorized 'the people,' but differed on means/institutions.
Jacksonian expansion of suffrage for white males contrasted with coercive Native policy.
Bank War symbolizes executive vs. financial elite conflict.

notes.title: FDR & the New Deal — Successes, Limits & Legacy
notes.content: Outline relief-recovery-reform, first 100 days, labor reforms, Social Security; note constitutional battles and that full recovery came with WWII mobilization.
keyTakeaways: Stabilized finance and reshaped federal role, but didn't fully end unemployment pre-WWII.
Built modern social safety net and labor rights framework.
Expect evaluative questions: save capitalism vs. expand state.

resources.title: Investopedia — Economic Effects of the New Deal

notes.title: Progressive Era (1900–1916) — Reforms & Limits
notes.content: Trust-busting, regulatory commissions, conservation, municipal reform, and democratizing measures (initiative, referendum). Note racial exclusions and limits.
keyTakeaways: Coalition of middle-class reformers + muckrakers + politicians.
Built administrative state foundations pre-New Deal.
Evaluate successes vs. blind spots (race, immigration).

resources.title: State Dept. Milestones — Progressive reforms context

notes.title: Civil Rights Trajectory — From Abolition to MLK
notes.content: Brief arc from Reconstruction Amendments to Jim Crow, then NAACP litigation, Brown, Civil Rights Act (1964), Voting Rights Act (1965), and MLK's non-violence philosophy.
keyTakeaways: Legal change + mass mobilization were complementary.
Federal courts and Congress pivotal after 1950s.
Remember Nobel Peace Prize date (1964) for MCQs.

notes.title: Marshall Plan (ERP) — Aims, Mechanics & Effects
notes.content: Economic recovery for Western Europe (1948–52) to stabilize allies/markets and contain communism; counterpart funds, OEEC coordination; U.S. domestic boost.
keyTakeaways: ~$13B aid; stimulated European recovery and U.S. exports.
Linked to containment architecture and Atlantic integration.
Know date of law (April 3, 1948) for MCQs.

notes.title: Truman Doctrine (1947) — Global Commitments
notes.content: Announced to support 'free peoples' (initially Greece/Turkey). Establishes open-ended U.S. responsibility and precedes ERP/NATO.
keyTakeaways: Sets ideological frame of Cold War aid/intervention.
Domestic politics: anti-communist consensus building.
Pairs logically with Marshall Plan in essays.

notes.title: George F. Kennan — Long Telegram & 'X' Article
notes.content: Outline the 1946 Long Telegram and 1947 'Sources of Soviet Conduct' arguing for patient, firm containment; note Kennan's later critique of militarized interpretations.
keyTakeaways: Foundational to U.S. Cold War strategy.
Stress economic/political pressure over war.
Great for short notes + historiography angles.

resources.title: Truman Library Institute — Long Telegram explainer

notes.title: Woodrow Wilson — Fourteen Points & Versailles
notes.content: Summarize key points (open diplomacy, self-determination, League) and Senate rejection of the Treaty due to Article X/partisan politics.
keyTakeaways: Idealism vs. domestic constraints is the exam's core contrast.
League failure shaped interwar U.S. isolationist tendencies.
Use direct quotations sparingly from primary text.

notes.title: Vietnam War — Gulf of Tonkin & Escalation
notes.content: Explain the August 1964 incidents, Tonkin Gulf Resolution's broad authorization, and later controversies about the evidence; connect to War Powers debates.
keyTakeaways: Tonkin Resolution passed 88–2 (Senate), 414–0 (House).
Became legal basis for large-scale escalation.
Later scrutiny fueled push for War Powers limits.

notes.title: Immigration — 'Nation of Nations' or 'Mixing Bowl'?
notes.content: Track major waves (Old/New immigration, 1965 reform), urbanization, nativism (Know-Nothings), and multicultural debates.
keyTakeaways: Immigration shaped labor markets, cities, and politics.
Exam often asks for model metaphors: melting pot vs. mosaic.
Use census snapshots + policy milestones (Chinese Exclusion, 1924 quota, 1965 Act).

notes.title: Women's Suffrage — From Seneca Falls to the 19th Amendment
notes.content: Outline movement phases (1848, state-level gains, WWI context), then 1920 ratification; add post-1920 feminist waves for continuity.
keyTakeaways: 19th Amendment ratified 1920 (MCQ favorite).
Coalitions and tactics evolved (legalism, protest, war service).
Link to later Equal Rights debates.

resources.title: National Archives — Women's rights docs hub

notes.title: Great Depression — Causes & Effects
notes.content: Synthesize structural weaknesses, monetary contraction, bank failures, unemployment, Dust Bowl; social impacts and policy experimentation.
keyTakeaways: Differentiate causes (1929 crash ≠ sole cause).
Use graphs/data points if time permits.
Segues into New Deal evaluation.

resources.title: Investopedia — Economic Effects of the New Deal (for outcomes link)

notes.title: U.S. Foreign Policy Since WWII — Big Arcs
notes.content: Containment (Europe/Asia), alliance-building (NATO), détente, post-Cold War unipolarity, War on Terror, and great-power competition re-emergence.
keyTakeaways: Connect doctrine → instruments (aid, alliances, interventions).
Use Kennan/Truman/Marshall → NATO as a through-line.

notes.title: Quick MCQ Pack — Foundational Facts
notes.content: Jamestown 1607; Mayflower 1620; Bill of Rights 1791; Paris Peace (1783) in Paris; Alaska from Russia (1867); FDR longest-serving; JFK & Apollo; Carter & Camp David; Reagan 'Evil Empire'; women's vote 1920.
keyTakeaways: Group facts by era for recall.
Make a 1-page date/name sheet.
Link dates to doctrines (e.g., 1823 Monroe).

notes.title: How to Attempt the CSS Paper (Structure & Timing)
notes.content: Typical paper: compulsory MCQs + essay section (pick 4). Do one constitutional or presidency question, one foreign-policy question, one social/economic movement question, and one thematic compare/contrast (e.g., Jeffersonian vs. Jacksonian).
keyTakeaways: Outline first; integrate 3–5 primary/authoritative references.
Use dates, names, and short quotes from documents sparingly.
Finish with a balanced judgment referencing historiography.

reference_texts.title: State Dept. Historian (Milestones in U.S. Foreign Relations)
